course_title: Realism, Fiction, and Factuality on Screen

learning_outcomes.description: Apply and test some of the key theoretical arguments in Film and TV Studies about relationships between the screen and the material, social, historical, and experiential aspects of the world.
Analyse realism, fiction, and truth in film and animation practices across different cultures and historical contexts, and discuss them clearly and with sensitivity.
Assess the impact of new technologies on practices of film and TV realism, and distinguish among different kinds of film/TV, their intentions, and potential impacts.
Explain ethical concerns about the responsibilities of film and TV producers to their audiences and those who images they use, and identify where these concerns do and don’t apply.
Closely analyse films and/or television programs, to produce evidence for arguments communicated via speech, writing, or video essay.
Synthesize and apply complex ideas about film and TV, and communicate them in compelling, meaningful ways to a target audience.

assessments.task_description:
One mark is available each week for seminar participation/engagement, for a total of ten marks over ten weeks. To receive the mark each week: write your name on the class sign-in sheet in the seminar room AND EITHER speak into the microphone (raise your hand, and I will bring it to you), OR write a response to a prompt or question on the seminar slides (or ask questions about the seminar topic) in the discussion space on blackboard. Discussion posts must engage with specific points from the seminar. Broad statements about a topic that do not refer to something specific from the seminar will receive a ‘0’.

If you are unable to attend the seminar due to a timetable clash, illness, or other good reason, email the course co-ordinator, Lisa, and she will arrange an alternative engagement activity so you can still earn the mark.

It is your responsibility to ensure your name is recorded on the sign-in sheet in class so that your participation can be marked, or email Lisa l.bode@uq.edu.au if you cannot make it to class.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Each week in tutorials (starting week 2) there will be a timed writing exercise that must be completed on the provided worksheet (you are responsible for bringing your own pen or pencil). Students are not permitted to access devices of any kind during the timed task, but may consult printed or handwritten notes. You will be given 15 minutes preparation time, and 15 minutes writing time.

The exercises will be different each week. Earlier ones will be concerned with applying that week’s concept to a screen case study. The later ones will be focused on generating ideas and drafting parts of the final assignment (the screening program or video essay with written introduction). This gives you the option to complete part of the work for the final assignment in workshops, receive marks for that draft work, as well as receive feedback as you progress.

Feedback will be given informally. Your tutor will collect the worksheets afterwards to record completion of the assessment task. Each writing task will be marked out of 5. Your best 8 workshop exercises will count towards your final mark out of 40. To check this grade during the semester, please ask your tutor.

Students who miss a number of classes due to illness or other factors beyond their control will be given a chance to do a makeup session in week 13.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Introduction

What do we mean when we use words like 'realism' or 'authenticity'' (or 'unrealistic', or 'inauthentic') to talk about films and TV shows? In what ways do these things seem to matter to how we value or devalue films and TV? How do we distinguish between fiction and non-fiction and what happens when these categories are mixed up?

This is the first seminar. We will discuss the aims and objectives of the course, introduce the main concepts, and explain the assessment.

See Blackboard (e-learning site) for more details.


Sub-activity: Tutorial

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Realism(s): Matters of screen style


In the first part of the course we examine fictional film and TV's various relationships to realism and reality. We start this week with screen production: what is realism in film production. How has 'realism' in filmmaking and screen production been defined in different places and times? When has realism just been about preserving an illusion? What have been seen as some of the 'stakes' of realism on screen?

See Blackboard (e-learning site) for required reading and viewing.

seminar participation/engagement is marked this week. In-class writing exercises start this week in the tutorials.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Realist Film Theories and the Camera


We turn from production (what filmmakers do to make their works seem 'real') to how film theorists have argued about the medium of film and its special relationship to reality. Why have the film camera and the photographic image been so central to realist film theories? How and why did these theories emerge? When is the camera's recording of reality most meaningful in our viewing of film and TV? What if anything is still useful about these theories for us in the age of computer generated images (CGI) and AI generated imagery?

See Blackboard for what to read and what to watch.

seminar participation/engagement is marked this week. In class writing task in tutoral.


Sub-activity: Tutorial

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: The sensory and emotional realities of the viewing experience

This week we look at the reality of the viewing experience, or how and why we respond 'as if it were real'. Most of us have cried or felt angry or exuberant watching a film. Some of us have thrown up. You may find your body making involuntary movements or felt the hairs prick up on your arms while watching the screen. How does this work? We often use words like 'visceral', 'sensuous', 'electrifying', 'overwhelming' when talking about films - for they are indeed not just stories told with moving images and sound on a 2D screen, but sensory and emotional experiences. How have phenomenologists and cognitive theorists of films tried to explain what happens in our bodies and minds when we watch? How have particular filmmakers had an interest in making films that we watch not just with our eyes and ears but our emotions, and our whole bodies?

See Blackboard for what to read and watch.

seminar participation/engagement is marked this week. In class writing task in tutoral.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6 Animation Aesthetics: From Realism to Abstraction

Film and TV is more than live action. It includes animation! But animation has often been neglected in film studies, in part because the early domination of realist film theory argued that the photographic image defined film as a medium (and therefore, animation was pushed to the margins - not 'really' film). Animation theorists though argue that animation has a range of really productive and interesting ways of emulating or commenting upon reality. It comprises a wide variety of styles, methods, and approaches. There is always a stylistic choice in how animation's bodies, spaces, and movements look. How has animation been theorised in relation to reality, and how has realism been defined in animation? How has it been discussed in relation to different modes, and in what ways are animation's various departures from realism seen to be central to its meanings?

See Blackboard for what to watch and read.

seminar participation/engagement is marked this week. In class writing task in tutoral.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Documenting reality, claiming truth.

This is the first week of the second half of the course - we turn from realism/reality on screen to the related question of truth and factuality on screen. Today we consider documentaries: what is a documentary? How and why has the definition of documentary changed over time? How do we differentiate between a documentary and other forms of media that claim to tell truths about the world? How do documentaries persuade us, what do documentaries do with evidence and rhetoric, and what approaches can they take to knowledge?

See Blackboard for what to watch and read.

seminar participation/engagement is marked this week. In class writing task in tutoral.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Animating realities and expressing truths in animated documentary

This week we examine animation in documentaries and animated documentary. If animation creates its own realities (worlds that exist only as animation), how can it also be used to help us understand our own realities or those of others? We look at how animation has been used in factual contexts to explain, express, and interrogate real events and experiences, communicate facts and data, and communicate things that cannot be captured by a camera.

See Blackboard for what to watch and read.

seminar participation/engagement is marked this week. In class writing task in tutoral.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Biopics and Docudrama

Guest seminar by Dr Melanie Piper

This week we look at how biopics turn real people into characters and docudrama turn real events into stories. what are the functions and fascinations of these forms of "based on a true story" screen media? how are they different from documentaries? how do they straddle the lines between factuality and fiction? what are their ethical dimensions?

See Blackboard for what to watch and read.

seminar participation/engagement is marked this week. In class writing task in tutoral.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Deepfakes and the uses and misuses of real people's images and lives

Deepfakes have generated a lot of anxiety and discussion about the ethics of using other people's images - about appropriation, recontextualisation, power, play, ethics, and harms. How do we decide what is a legitimate, creative use of someone's likeness, and what is an unethical or harmful use? How might this connect to other ways in which film and TV creators use the images and stories of others, such as in true crime or biopics?

See Blackboard for what to watch and read.

seminar participation/engagement is marked this week. In class writing task in tutoral.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Ambiguous truths, deceptions, satire, and AI Generated video

In this final topic we examine screen works that have ambiguous or playful relationships to truth, history, and memory, and consider how AI tools (for colorisation of black and white film, dubbing, for instance) and AI Generated vintage video may be fundamentally transforming our relationship to the audio-visual archive and our perceptions of the past. Do we still care about what is real/fake, true/fabrication, and, if so, why, and how do we keep the distinction alive?

To prepare, please watch: My Winnipeg (Guy Maddin, 2007) or 24 Hour Party People (Michael Winterbottom, 2002). Please check Blackboard for readings.

Participation/engagement will be graded this week (last one).


Sub-activity: Tutorial
